keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Fengshen is approaching the Philippine coast, prompting over 9,000 residents of Catanduanes island to evacuate due to risks of coastal flooding and high winds.
Catanduanes, with a population of 270,000, is a frequently impacted region due to its location in the western Pacific and its vulnerability to cyclones.
The Philippines experiences an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, with many affecting impoverished, disaster-prone communities.
Scientists link the increasing intensity of storms to climate change, as global warming contributes to more powerful and unpredictable tropical systems.

The country is still recovering from a series of major earthquakes and typhoons in recent weeks, including a magnitude 6.9 and a magnitude 7.4 earthquake, which caused fatalities and triggered tsunami warnings.
Evacuations in Catanduanes are often part of regular drills, indicating that the island has a history of being one of the first landmasses affected by western Pacific cyclones.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches the Philippine coast, over 9,000 residents of the island of Catanduanes have evacuated due to risks of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters high and strong winds of up to 80 km/h. The evacuation is part of a recurring drill, as Catanduanes is often among the first landmasses affected by cyclones in the western Pacific. The Philippines, which faces an average of 20 typhoons annually, is still recovering from a recent series of major earthquakes and typhoons, including a 6.9 and a 7.4 magnitude quake, which caused fatalities and triggered tsunami warnings. Scientists warn that increasing storm intensity is linked to global climate change, indicating a growing threat to vulnerable, impoverished communities in disaster-prone regions.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
